Hi Elliote,

On 1/24/06, Elliotte Harold <elharo@...> wrote:
>
=
> Subscribers to this mailing list might be interest in an ongoing
> discus=
sion on The Cafes about Experimental Programming:
>
> http://cafe.elharo.co=
m/java/experimental-programming/
>
> In brief, I relate the story of a bug =
fix in XOM, and argue for the
> primacy of testing and experiment over clai=
med understanding of code.


I think this is a very bad idea.

The first fi=
x should have been a warning to you:  you made a quick change,
thought you =
were done, shipped the new version and then someone else pointed
out that y=
our fix had created a deeper, more subtle bug.

Instead of learning the obv=
ious lesson from that mistake (which is "try to
understand the code you are=
 modifying"), you repeat it and fix the second
bug with another one-line ha=
ck without any good reason, using the
justification "the tests are passing,=
 so I'm okay".

Well, yes, if you assume that your tests are 100% perfect. =
 They were not
the first time, why do you assume they are now?

To make mat=
ter worse, you claim:

I think some of the people posting here don't realiz=
e just how comprehensive
XOM's test suite is.

Don't you have enough proof =
that you are overestimating the
comprehensiveness of these tests since they=
 failed to catch two bugs in a
short period of time?

Note that I totally u=
nderstand the necessity to do "hack fixing" when
circumstances warrant it (=
deadlines, pressing customer, etc...), but
recommending it as a new way of =
development is irresponsible.

But I guess the best illustration of this po=
int is the following comment
from one of your readers:

I'm having a seriou=
s rethink about using XOM.

--
C=E9dric
